content.description: After a juggy start this line sneaks up the nearly blank center section of the north face on barely there holds leading to a committing topout. It’s most likely easier if you’re taller.
content.location: Stand start just to the left of the rainbow shaped rail using a RH pocket and a blade-like jug for the LH. From the start climb up and slightly left using a crimpy 2 or 3 finger pocket for the RH and a tiny divot for the LH to make a pretty long move to the lip.

content.description: This is a fairly easy problem on good rock.
content.location: In about the center of the tall vertical face, SDS below the obvious rainbow shaped rail using a RH sidepull and LH pocket. Move up to match on the rail, then climb up and slightly right on great holds.

content.description: A neat problem on really good rock that avoids the bad landing potential of the other climbs on this boulder. Features a devious crux move to a small pocket.
content.protection: 1-2 crashpads, a spotter could help prevent a fall down the steep slope to the right.
content.location: This one is located on the bulging NE corner above a flat slab rather than the obvious tall face. Start with RH in a good pocket and LH on sloping rail. Move the RH up into a sloping pocket, then do a really hard move up with the left to a small slot like pocket which is the crux. Once the crux hold is latched move up and right on slopers and pockets to the obvious large hueco that is just before the topout.

content.description: This boulder features a tall vertical face that was nearly completely hidden by large Juniper trees before the 2017 ice storm wreaked havoc on the trees, so not as woodsy as it once was. This is one of the taller faces in the canyon and the landing slopes steeply downhill so creative pad placement and spotters would increase the safety factor. The uphill corner offers a good line with a much more forgiving landing. **Since this page was created the area around this boulder has been defaced by a church group/cult who excavated a bunch of dirt to create a spot for their rituals from the uphill side and dumped it on the downhill side, particularly on the slab where the sit start for Into the Woods is located. Everything is still climbable but the damage is a downer.
